address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biology and Wildlife; Institute of Arctic Biology: University of Alaska Fairbanks 193 Arctic Health P.O. Box 757000

abstract.para: This study considers the relative role of competition and facilitation in primary succession of the boreal forest floodplain of Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest. Alder (Alnus tenuifolia Nutt.) is an early colonist of young floodplain sites, where it contributes greatly to soil development through the addition of nitrogen to the soil. White spruce (Picea glauca (Moench.) Voss) typically colonizes such sites later; it becomes established beneath a canopy of alder and willow (Salix spp.) which is sometimes overtopped by young balsam poplar (Populus balsamifera L.). The alder may potentially influence white spruce both positively and negatively. Possible facilitative effects include protection of small seedlings from excess heat or heavy siltation accompanying flooding and addition of soil nitrogen, an effect that may extend for many years. Competition for light (and other resources) before the white spruce has overtopped the alder canopy may prove to be a major negative effects. This study seeks to determine the net balance of these effects on the floodplain successional sequence.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para:
Three types of 20 m x 20 m artificial communities were established on each of six replicate early successional sites (two replicates at each of three LTER sites): pure spruce plots planted at 1 m spacing, plots with spruce mixed with alder (spruce planted at 1 m spacing, alder planted between spruce seedlings), and pure spruce in which N fertilizer will be added (N was never added). As a result of bank erosion, several of the plots at FP1A were destroyed, and that site was eliminated.
Pure spuirce plots (also referred to as communities) were assigned the designator "PS" (PS1, PS2, PS3, and PS4). Mixed alder and spruce plots (also referred to as communities) were assigned the designator "AS" (AS2 and AS2).

section.title: Methods
section.para:
White spruce seedlings were planted at 1 m spacing in the summer of 1989. During the first 2 years of the study dead seedlings were replaced. After 3 years each individual white spruce seedling was located and tagged, and its condition noted. Height measurements were made of all seedlings (both white spruce and alder) in 1992 and repeated in 1995. Alder heights were determined in 1995 by standing on a ladder at the end of each row and using binoculars to read the heights on a surveying Philadelphia Rod.
In 2002 we remeasured spruce heights and condition and harvested quadrates in each plot to estimate above ground biomass and total soil and plant N and C accumulation. In 2003 we generated allometric equations relating alder DBH to alder biomass. We estimated total alder biomass in each by using these equations with our estimates of alder stem densities and DBH.

dataTable.entityDescription:
This file contains data about alder and spruce seedling growth from the artificial communities experiment over a 10 year peiod. Measurements were made in 1992, 1995 and 2002. Alder and spruce were sampled in 1992 and 1995, but only spruce were measured in 2002. The foloowing measurements were made:
Spruce measurements in 1992: height (cm), survival (dead=0, alive=1)
Alder measurements in 1992: height (cm), survival (dead=0, alive=1)
Spruce measurements in 1995: height (cm), survival (dead=0, alive=1)
Alder measurements in 1995: height (cm), survival (dead=0, alive=1)
Spruce measurements in 2002: height (cm), survival (dead=0, alive=1), missing/found (missing=0, found=1), not browsed/browsed (not browsed=0, browsed=1), health (appears healthy=0, appears unhealthy=1), physical disturbance (no obvious disturbance=0, flattened and/or partially buried in silt=1), spruce growing near a naturally occurring alder in pure spruce plots (not near alder=0, near alder=1)
Each row of data contains the following:
Year of measurement, Site (FP1B or FP1C), Plot (pure spruce = PS1-PS4, spruce/alder mix = SA1-SA2), Seedling number (white spruce seedling number indicates the planted row and distance from beginning of row: for example 101 means row 1 and a distance of 1 meter; 1021 means row 10 and a distance of 21 meters)
